sen.j: 崇源院（すうげんいん、天正元年〔1573年〕- 寛永3年9月15日 (旧暦)〔1626年11月3日〕）は、天正時代から江戸時代初期の女性。
sen.e: Sugen-in (1573 - November 3, 1626) was a woman from Tensho period to the early Edo period.
Sugen-in (1573 - November 3, 1626) was a woman who lived from the Tensho period to the early Edo period.
Sugen-in (1573 - November 3, 1626) was a woman who lived from the Tensho period to the early Edo period.

sen.j: 諱は江／小督（おごう）もしくは江与（えよ）とされるが、再婚時に改名した可能性もあり、どの名が正しいのかは確定できていない。
sen.e: Her imina (personal name) is considered Go, Ogo, or Eyo, however, she could have changed her name at the time of her second marriage, thus which name was true has not been determined.
Her imina (personal name) is considered Go, Ogo, or Eyo, however, she could have changed her name at the time of her second marriage, thus which name was true has not been determined.

sen.j: 従一位の位階を賜った際には朝廷から「達子」（さとこ）の諱を受けた。
sen.e: When she received the Ikai (Court rank) of Juichii (Junior First Rank), she was given imina 'Satoko' from the Imperial Court.
When she received the Ikai (Court rank) of Juichii (Junior First Rank), she was given imina 'Satoko' from the Imperial Court.
When she received the Ikai (Court rank) of Juichii (Junior First Rank), she was given imina 'Satoko' from the Imperial Court.

sen.j: 生年には異説もある。
sen.e: Regarding her year of birth, there is a different opinion.
Regarding her year of birth, there are different opinions.

sen.j: 浅井長政の三女。
sen.e: She was the third daughter of Nagamasa AZAI.
She was the third daughter of Nagamasa AZAI.
She was the third daughter of Nagamasa AZAI.

sen.j: 母は織田信秀の娘・お市の方（織田信長の妹。
sen.e: Her mother was Oichi no kata, a daughter of Nobuhide ODA (a younger sister of Nobunaga ODA.)
Her mother was Oichi no kata, a daughter of Nobuhide ODA (a younger sister of Nobunaga ODA).
Her mother was Oichi no kata, a daughter of Nobuhide ODA (a younger sister of Nobunaga ODA).

sen.j: 長姉の淀殿（茶々）は豊臣秀吉側室、次姉・常高院（初）は京極高次正室。
sen.e: Her eldest sister Yodo-dono (Chacha) was a concubine of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, and her second eldest sister Joko-in (Hatsu) was a lawful wife of Takatsugu KYOGOKU.
Her eldest sister Yodo-dono (Chacha) was a concubine of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, and her second eldest sister Joko-in (Hatsu) was a lawful wife of Takatsugu KYOGOKU.
Her eldest sister Yodo-dono (Chacha) was a concubine of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, and her second eldest sister Joko-in (Hatsu) was a lawful wife of Takatsugu KYOGOKU.

sen.j: 最初の婚姻相手は佐治一成で、その後離縁させられる。
sen.e: Sugen-in's first marriage partner was Kazunari SAJI, but later she was divorced.
Sugen-in's first marriage partner was Kazunari SAJI, but later she was divorced.
Sugen-in's first marriage partner was Kazunari SAJI, but later she was divorced.

sen.j: 2度目の婚姻相手は豊臣秀勝、のち死別。
sen.e: Her second marriage partner was Hidekatsu TOYOTOMI, but later she was widowed.
Her second marriage partner was Hidekatsu TOYOTOMI, but later she was widowed.
Her second marriage partner was Hidekatsu TOYOTOMI, but later she was widowed.

sen.j: 三度目は江戸幕府二代将軍徳川秀忠に再々嫁し、秀忠の正室（継室）となる。
sen.e: At the third time, she got married to Hidetada TOKUGAWA, the second shogun of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), and became a seishitsu (legal wife) (keishitsu [second wife]) of Hidetada.

The third time, she got married to Hidetada TOKUGAWA, the second shogun of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), and became a seishitsu (legal wife) (keishitsu [second wife]) of Hidetada.

The third time, she got married to Hidetada TOKUGAWA, the second shogun of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), and became a seishitsu (legal wife) (keishitsu [second wife]) of Hidetada.

sen.j: また、第109代明正天皇の外祖母でもある。
sen.e: In addition, she was a maternal grandmother of the Emperor Meisho, the 109th.
In addition, she was the maternal grandmother of the Emperor Meisho, the 109th.
In addition, she was the maternal grandmother of the Emperor Meisho, the 109th.

sen.j: 天正元年（1573年）、浅井長政の三女として近江国小谷（滋賀県湖北町）に生まれる。
sen.e: In 1573, Sugen-in was born in Odani, Omi Province (Kohoku-cho, Shiga Prefecture) as the third daughter of Nagamasa AZAI.
In 1573, Sugen-in was born in Odani, Omi Province (Kohoku-cho, Shiga Prefecture) as the third daughter of Nagamasa AZAI.

sen.j: 母は織田信秀の娘・お市の方。
sen.e: Her mother was Oichi no kata, a daughter of Nobuhide ODA.
Her mother was Oichi no kata, a daughter of Nobuhide ODA.
Her mother was Oichi no kata, a daughter of Nobuhide ODA.

sen.j: 9月1日（1573年9月26日）、父・長政が妻・市の兄・織田信長と対立し、小谷城が攻め落とされた。
sen.e: On September 26, 1573, her father Nagamasa had a conflict with Nobunaga ODA, his wife Ichi's elder brother, and Odani-jo Castle was captured by Nobunaga.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: On September 26, 1573, her father Nagamasa had a conflict with Nobunaga ODA, his wife Ichi's elder brother, and Odani-jo Castle was captured by Nobunaga.
On September 26, 1573, her father Nagamasa had a conflict with Nobunaga ODA, his wife Ichi's elder brother, and Odani-jo Castle was captured by Nobunaga.

sen.j: 父・長政、祖父・浅井久政が自刃すると母・市、姉・淀殿、常高院とともに城を逃れ信長に保護される。
sen.e: When her father Nagamasa and her grandfather Hisamasa AZAI killed themselves, Sugen-in escaped from the castle together with her mother Ichi, elder sisters Yodo-dono and Joko-in, and they were protected by Nobunaga.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: When her father Nagamasa and her grandfather Hisamasa AZAI killed themselves, Sugen-in escaped from the castle together with her mother Ichi, elder sisters Yodo-dono and Joko-in, and they were protected by Nobunaga.

When her father Nagamasa and her grandfather Hisamasa AZAI killed themselves, Sugen-in escaped from the castle together with her mother Ichi, elder sisters Yodo-dono and Joko-in, and they were protected by Nobunaga.

sen.j: この時、兄・万福丸は信長の命により殺されている。
sen.e: At that time, her elder brother Manpukumaru was killed by the order of Nobunaga.
At that time, her elder brother Manpukumaru was killed by the order of Nobunaga.
At that time, her elder brother Manpukumaru was killed by the order of Nobunaga.

sen.j: 天正10年（1582年）、6月2日本能寺の変で伯父・信長が家臣・明智光秀に殺され、6月27日後継者を決める清洲会議により母・市は信長の家臣・柴田勝家と再婚し越前国北ノ庄城へ移る。
sen.e: In 1582, her uncle Nobunaga was killed by his vassal Mitsuhide AKECHI in the Honnoji Incident on June 2, and in the Kiyosu conference for deciding Nobunaga's successor on June 27, her mother Ichi got remarried to Katsuie SHIBATA, the vassal of Nobunaga, and moved to the castle in Kitanosho of Echizen Province.

In 1582, her uncle Nobunaga was killed by his vassal Mitsuhide AKECHI in the Honnoji Incident on June 2, and in the Kiyosu conference for deciding Nobunaga's successor on June 27, her mother Ichi got remarried to Katsuie SHIBATA, the vassal of Nobunaga, and moved to the castle in Kitanosho of Echizen Province.

In 1582, her uncle Nobunaga was killed by his vassal Mitsuhide AKECHI in the Honnoji Incident on June 2, and in the Kiyosu conference for deciding Nobunaga's successor on June 27, her mother Ichi got remarried to Katsuie SHIBATA, the vassal of Nobunaga, and moved to the castle in Kitanosho of Echizen Province.

sen.j: 天正11年（1583年）、賤ヶ岳の戦いで北ノ庄城が落城、勝家と市の自害後は豊臣秀吉の元へ保護される。
sen.e: In 1583, the Kitanosho-jo Castle fell to the enemy in the Battle of Shizugatake, and Sugen-in was protected under Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI after the suicide of Katsuie and Ichi.
In 1583, the Kitanosho-jo Castle fell to the enemy in the Battle of Shizugatake, and Sugen-in was protected under Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI after the suicide of Katsuie and Ichi.
In 1583, the Kitanosho-jo Castle fell to the enemy in the Battle of Shizugatake, and Sugen-in was protected under Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI after the suicide of Katsuie and Ichi.

sen.j: 天正12年（1584年）、秀吉の命により母の姉（織田信長妹お犬の方）の子・佐治一成へ嫁ぐ。
sen.e: In 1584, Sugen-in got married to Kazunari SAJI, a child of her mother's elder sister (Nobunaga ODA's younger sister Oinu no kata), by the order of Hideyoshi.
In 1584, Sugen-in got married to Kazunari SAJI, a child of her mother's elder sister (Nobunaga ODA's younger sister Oinu no kata), by the order of Hideyoshi.
In 1584, Sugen-in got married to Kazunari SAJI, a child of her mother's elder sister (Nobunaga ODA's younger sister Oinu no kata), by the order of Hideyoshi.

sen.j: だが一成が小牧・長久手の戦いで伯父・信長の跡継ぎのことで秀吉と不和になった母の甥・織田信雄（織田信長次男）を擁立した徳川家康に味方したため秀吉の怒りに触れた一成は秀吉から所領を没収されるとともに離縁させられた。
sen.e: However, in Battle of Komaki and Nagakute, Kazunari took the side of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA supporting Nobukatsu ODA (the second son of Nobunaga ODA), who was a nephew of his mother and in discord with Hideyoshi due to the successor to his uncle Nobunaga, so that Kazunari who angered Hideyoshi was confiscated his territory and divorced by Hideyoshi.

However, in Battle of Komaki and Nagakute, Kazunari took the side of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA supporting Nobukatsu ODA (the second son of Nobunaga ODA), who was a nephew of his mother and in discord with Hideyoshi due to the successor to his uncle Nobunaga, so that Kazunari who angered Hideyoshi had his territory confiscated and was cut off from Hideyoshi.

However, in Battle of Komaki and Nagakute, Kazunari took the side of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA supporting Nobukatsu ODA (the second son of Nobunaga ODA), who was a nephew of his mother and in discord with Hideyoshi due to the successor to his uncle Nobunaga, so that Kazunari who angered Hideyoshi had his territory confiscated and was cut off from Sugen-in.
sen.cmt: 離縁ということなのでSugen-inとしました。

sen.j: 文禄元年1592年、再び秀吉の命により秀吉の甥・豊臣秀勝（小吉秀勝。関白秀次弟）の元へ嫁ぎ、同年豊臣完子（九条幸家室）を産むが、文禄・慶長の役で秀勝は死去。
sen.e: In 1592, Sugen-in got married to Hideyoshi's nephew Hidekatsu TOYOTOMI (Kokichi Hidekatsu, younger brother of Chancellor Hidetsugu) by the order of Hideyoshi again, and in the same year, she bore Sadako TOYOTOMI (wife of Yukiie KUJO), but Hidekatsu died in the Bunroku-Keicho War.

In 1592, Sugen-in got married to Hideyoshi's nephew Hidekatsu TOYOTOMI (Kokichi Hidekatsu, younger brother of Chancellor Hidetsugu) by the order of Hideyoshi again, and in the same year, she bore Sadako TOYOTOMI (wife of Yukiie KUJO), but Hidekatsu died in the Bunroku-Keicho War.

In 1592, Sugen-in got married to Hideyoshi's nephew Hidekatsu TOYOTOMI (Kokichi Hidekatsu, younger brother of Chancellor Hidetsugu) by the order of Hideyoshi again, and in the same year, she bore Sadako TOYOTOMI (wife of Yukiie KUJO), but Hidekatsu died in the Bunroku-Keicho War.

sen.j: 文禄4年（1595年）9月17日家康の三男・秀忠に嫁す（再々婚）。
sen.e: September 17, 1595, Sugen-in got married to Hidetada, the third son of Ieyasu (third marriage.)
September 17, 1595, Sugen-in got married to Hidetada, the third son of Ieyasu (third marriage).
September 17, 1595, Sugen-in got married to Hidetada, the third son of Ieyasu (third marriage).

sen.j: なお、前夫・秀勝との子である完子は長姉・茶々（淀殿）の猶子として引き取られる。
sen.e: Sadako, a child by her former husband Hidekatsu was fostered by her eldest sister Chacha (Yodo-dono) as an adopted child.
Sadako, a child by her former husband Hidekatsu, was fostered by her eldest sister Chacha (Yodo-dono) as an adopted child.
Sadako, a child by her former husband Hidekatsu, was fostered by her eldest sister Chacha (Yodo-dono) as an adopted child.

sen.j: 慶長2年（1597年5月26日）、千姫（豊臣秀頼室、のちに本多忠刻室）を京都伏見城内徳川屋敷で出産。
sen.e: On May 26, 1597, Sugen-in bore Senhime (wife of Hideyori TOYOTOMI, later, wife of Tadatoki HONDA) in residence of Tokugawa in Fushimi-jo Castle in Kyoto.
On May 26, 1597, Sugen-in bore Senhime (wife of Hideyori TOYOTOMI, later, wife of Tadatoki HONDA) in the residence of Tokugawa in Fushimi-jo Castle in Kyoto.
On May 26, 1597, Sugen-in bore Senhime (wife of Hideyori TOYOTOMI, later, wife of Tadatoki HONDA) in the residence of Tokugawa in Fushimi-jo Castle in Kyoto.

sen.j: 秀頼の母は秀吉の側室となった長姉・茶々である。
sen.e: Hideyori's mother was her eldest sister Chacha, who was the concubine of Hideyoshi.
Hideyori's mother was her eldest sister Chacha, who was the concubine of Hideyoshi.
Hideyori's mother was her eldest sister Chacha, who was the concubine of Hideyoshi.

sen.j: また、再嫁した本多忠刻の母は義父・家康の長男で秀忠の長兄松平信康と信長の長女・徳姫の娘である。
sen.e: Further, the mother of Tadatoki HONDA, Senhime's remarriage partner, was a daughter of Nobuyasu MATSUDAIRA, who was the first son of Sugen-in's father-in-law Ieyasu and the eldest brother of Hidetada, and Tokuhime, the first daughter of Nobunaga.

Further, the mother of Tadatoki HONDA, Senhime's remarriage partner, was a daughter of Nobuyasu MATSUDAIRA, who was the first son of Sugen-in's father-in-law Ieyasu and the eldest brother of Hidetada, and Tokuhime, the first daughter of Nobunaga.

Further, the mother of Tadatoki HONDA, Senhime's remarriage partner, was a daughter of Nobuyasu MATSUDAIRA, who was the first son of Sugen-in's father-in-law Ieyasu and the eldest brother of Hidetada, and Tokuhime, the first daughter of Nobunaga.

sen.j: 慶長4年（1599年）、珠姫（前田利常室、前田光高の母）を江戸城で出産。
sen.e: In 1599, Sugen-in bore Tamahime (wife of Toshitsune MAEDA, and mother of Mitsutaka MAEDA) in Edo-jo Castle.
In 1599, Sugen-in bore Tamahime (wife of Toshitsune MAEDA, and mother of Mitsutaka MAEDA) in Edo-jo Castle.
In 1599, Sugen-in bore Tamahime (wife of Toshitsune MAEDA, and mother of Mitsutaka MAEDA) in Edo-jo Castle.

sen.j: 慶長6年（1601年6月12日）、勝姫 (天崇院)（松平忠直室）を江戸城で出産。
sen.e: On June 12, 1601, she bore Katsuhime (Tensu-in, wife of Tadanao MATSUDAIRA) in Edo-jo Castle.
On June 12, 1601, she bore Katsuhime (Tensu-in, wife of Tadanao MATSUDAIRA) in Edo-jo Castle.
On June 12, 1601, she bore Katsuhime (Tensu-in, wife of Tadanao MATSUDAIRA) in Edo-jo Castle.

sen.j: 松平忠直は義父家康の次男・秀忠次兄の結城秀康（松平秀康）の長男。
sen.e: Tadanao MATSUDAIRA was the first son of Hideyasu YUKI (Hideyasu MATSUDAIRA), who was the second son of her father-in-law Ieyasu and the second eldest brother of Hidetada.
Tadanao MATSUDAIRA was the first son of Hideyasu YUKI (Hideyasu MATSUDAIRA), who was the second son of her father-in-law Ieyasu and the second eldest brother of Hidetada.

sen.j: 慶長7年（1602年8月25日）、初姫（京極忠高室）を伏見城（一説には、江戸城）で出産。
sen.e: On August 25, 1602, she bore Hatsuhime (wife of Tadataka KYOGOKU) in Fushimi-jo Castle (Edo-jo Castle, according to one estimate.)
On August 25, 1602, she bore Hatsuhime (wife of Tadataka KYOGOKU) in Fushimi-jo Castle (Edo-jo Castle, according to one estimate.)
On August 25, 1602, she bore Hatsuhime (wife of Tadataka KYOGOKU) in Fushimi-jo Castle (Edo-jo Castle, according to one estimate.)

sen.j: 京極家は次姉・初（常高院）の嫁ぎ先。
sen.e: The Kyogoku family was the husband' family of her second eldest sister Hatsu (Joko-in.)
The Kyogoku family was the family of her second eldest sister's husband Hatsu (Joko-in).
The Kyogoku family was the family of the husband of her second eldest sister Hatsu (Joko-in).
sen.cmt: NC後、原文と異なるため再修正しました。

sen.j: だが、忠高は常高院の実子ではなく側室の子。
sen.e: However, Tadataka was not Joko-in's biological child but a child of a concubine.
However, Tadataka was not Joko-in's biological child but a child of a concubine.
However, Tadataka was not Joko-in's biological child but a child of a concubine.

sen.j: 慶長9年（1604年）8月12日、徳川家光を江戸城で出産。
sen.e: On August 12, 1604, Sugen-in bore Iemitsu TOKUGAWA in Edo-jo Castle.
On August 12, 1604, Sugen-in bore Iemitsu TOKUGAWA in Edo-jo Castle.
On August 12, 1604, Sugen-in bore Iemitsu TOKUGAWA in Edo-jo Castle.

sen.j: 慶長11年（1606年）、徳川忠長を江戸城で出産。
sen.e: In 1606, she bore Tadanaga TOKUGAWA in Edo-jo Castle.
In 1606, she bore Tadanaga TOKUGAWA in Edo-jo Castle.
In 1606, she bore Tadanaga TOKUGAWA in Edo-jo Castle.

sen.j: 慶長12年10月4日（1607年11月23日）、徳川和子（後水尾天皇中宮、明正天皇母）を江戸城で出産。
sen.e: On November 23, 1607, she bore Masako TOKUGAWA (wife of Emperor Gomizunoo and mother of Emperor Meisho) in Edo-jo Castle.
On November 23, 1607, she bore Masako TOKUGAWA (wife of Emperor Gomizunoo and mother of Emperor Meisho) in Edo-jo Castle.
On November 23, 1607, she bore Masako TOKUGAWA (wife of Emperor Gomizunoo and mother of Emperor Meisho) in Edo-jo Castle.

sen.j: 寛永3年（1626年）9月15日、江戸城西の丸で死去、享年54。
sen.e: She died on September 15, 1626 at age 54 in nishi no maru (a castle compound to the west of the main compound) of Edo-jo Castle.
She died on September 15, 1626, at age 54 in nishi no maru (a castle compound to the west of the main compound) of Edo-jo Castle.

sen.j: 法名は「崇源院昌誉和興仁清」。
sen.e: Her homyo (a Buddhist name given to a person who has died or has entered the priesthood) is 'Sugen-in 昌誉和興仁清.'
sen.cmt: 「崇源院昌誉和興仁清」は読み方不明です。
sen.e: Her homyo (a Buddhist name given to a person who has died or has entered the priesthood) is 'Sugen-in 昌誉和興仁清.'

sen.j: この時、秀忠・家光・忠長は上洛中であった。
sen.e: When she died, Hidetada, Iemitsu and Tadanaga were during a visit to Kyoto.
When she died, Hidetada, Iemitsu and Tadanaga were visiting to Kyoto.
When she died, Hidetada, Iemitsu and Tadanaga were visiting to Kyoto.

sen.j: 寛永3年（1626年）11月28日、従一位を追贈される。
sen.e: On November 28, 1626, Sugen-in was given Juichii (Junior First Rank) after her death.
On November 28, 1626, Sugen-in was given Juichii (Junior First Rank) after her death.
On November 28, 1626, Sugen-in was given Juichii (Junior First Rank) after her death.

sen.j: 徳川将軍御台所（正室）で将軍生母となったのは後にも先にも彼女だけである。
sen.e: She was the first and the last Tokugawa Shogun Midaidokoro (wife of a shogun) (seishitsu [legal wife]) who became a real mother of shogun.
She was the first and the last Tokugawa Shogun Midaidokoro (wife of a shogun) (seishitsu [legal wife]) who became a real mother of shogun.
She was the first and the last Tokugawa Shogun Midaidokoro (wife of a shogun) (seishitsu [legal wife]) who became a real mother of shogun.

sen.j: 親族の死、政略や実家の跡継ぎ争いに巻き込まれた前半生とは違い、将軍御台所・将軍生母として安定した後半生を過ごした。
sen.e: Unlike the first half of her life, which was involved in deaths of family, the game of politics, and succession conflict in her parents' home, she had a stable second half of life as a shogun's wife and a real mother of shogun.

Unlike the first half of her life, which was involved in deaths of family, the game of politics, and succession conflict in her parents' home, the second half of life as a shogun's wife and a real mother of shogun was stable.

Unlike the first half of her life, which was involved in deaths of family, the game of politics, and succession conflict in her parents' home, the second half of life as a shogun's wife and a real mother of shogun was stable.

sen.j: 死後、江は二男・家光が増上寺（東京都港区 (東京都)）に埋葬した。
sen.e: After her death, Go was buried by the second son Iemitsu in Zojo-ji Temple (Minato Ward, Tokyo [Tokyo.])
After her death, Go was buried by the second son Iemitsu in Zojo-ji Temple (Minato Ward, Tokyo [Tokyo.])
After her death, Go was buried by the second son Iemitsu in Zojo-ji Temple (Minato Ward, Tokyo [Tokyo.])

sen.j: 戦後、鈴木尚が中心となって行なわれた増上寺の徳川家墓所発掘調査の際に、崇源院の墓も発掘され、その遺骨も調査された。
sen.e: When the excavation and research of graveyards of the Tokugawa family in Zojo-ji Temple, which was led by Hisashi SUZUKI, was conducted after the war, Sugen-in's grave was also excavated and her cremains were researched.

When the excavation and research of graveyards of the Tokugawa family in Zojo-ji Temple, which was led by Hisashi SUZUKI, was conducted after the war, Sugen-in's grave was also excavated and her remains were researched.

sen.j: それによると、火葬にされており、生前の崇源院はかなり小柄で華奢な美女であったようである。
sen.e: According to the research, she was cremated, and it seems that Sugen-in in life was a fairly small and slightly build beautiful woman.

sen.j: ちなみに増上寺に葬られた将軍一門で荼毘に付されていたのは崇源院だけであった。
sen.e: In fact, in the Shogun family who were buried in Zojo-ji Temple, only Sugen-in was cremated.

sen.j: 淀殿（茶々）・常高院（初）・崇源院（江）のいわゆる「浅井三姉妹」は、「戦国一数奇な運命を辿った姉妹」として知られる。
sen.e: Yodo-dono (Chacha), Joko-in (Hatsu) and Sugen-in (Go), so-called 'the three sisters of AZAI' were known as 'sisters who followed the strangest fate in the warlike period.'
Yodo-dono (Chacha), Joko-in (Hatsu) and Sugen-in (Go), so-called 'the three sisters of AZAI' were known as 'sisters who followed the strangest fate in the warlike period.'

sen.j: いずれも母・市の美貌を受け継いだ美女で、幼い頃からたいへん仲の良い姉妹だったと伝えられる。
sen.e: It is said that they were all beautiful women inheriting their mother Ichi's beauty and they were very close with each other from their childhood.
It is said that they were all beautiful women inheriting their mother Ichi's beauty and they were very close with each other from their childhood.

sen.j: だが実のところ、これほど身分が高く歴史的にも重要な人物でありながら、崇源院の容貌・性格などを含めた人物像を伝える確たる史料は少ない。
sen.e: In fact, however, even though Sugen-in was the historically important person in the high position, there is few creditable historical materials which report her personality including her looks and character.

sen.j: 小説・ドラマなどでは、前述のイメージや、夫・秀忠との関係から類推して、美貌で誇り高いがヒステリックで嫉妬深い性格の人物として描かれる事が多い。
sen.e: In novels and dramas, she is often depicted as a woman of beauty and great pride but hysterical and jealous character by analogy with the above-mentioned her image and a relation between her husband Hidetada.

In novels and dramas, she is often depicted as a woman of beauty and great pride but hysterical and jealous character by analogy with the above-mentioned reputation and the relation between her husband Hidetada.

sen.j: が、作家永井路子は彼女を母や姉達ほど美人でもなく機転が利く訳でもないが、どんな運命に巻き込まれても平然と受け流し、その度に魅力を増していく女性という、全く別の解釈をしている。
sen.e: However, a novelist Michiko NAGAI made a completely different explanation that Sugen-in was not so beautiful as her mother and sisters and not quick-witted, but she could calmly take any fate in her stride and added charms to herself each time she got over it.

sen.j: 夫・秀忠は江と結婚して以降、浮気はあったが正式な側室は1人ももたなかった。
sen.e: Since the marriage to Go, her husband Hidetada had affairs but did not have any formal concubines.
After marriage to Go, her husband Hidetada had affairs but did not have any formal concubines.

sen.j: 彼女が秀忠より年上で、嫉妬深い性格であったため、律義な性格であった秀忠は頭が上がらなかったとされるが、それだけ魅力のある女性ではあったようだ。
sen.e: It is said that since she was older than Hidetada and jealous, Hidetada, who was dutiful by character, could not say no to his wife, however, it could be said she was such an appealing woman.

sen.j: また、春日局との対立から、「自ら養育した（これはあり得ない。実際には忠長も乳母が養育した）」三男・忠長を溺愛し二男・家光を疎み廃嫡を企てる悪女のイメージも強い。
sen.e: Further, because of confrontation with Kasuga no tsubone, Sugen-in has a strong image of a wicked woman who doted on her third son Tadanaga that 'she brought up by herself (it was impossible, in fact, Tadanaga was also raised by a nanny)', disfavored her second son Iemitu and plotted to disinheritance of him.

sen.cmt: use of a noun as a verb
sen.e: Further, because of confrontation with Kasuga no tsubone, Sugen-in has a strong image of a wicked woman who doted on her third son Tadanaga that 'she brought up by herself (it was impossible, in fact, Tadanaga was also raised by a nanny)', disfavored her second son Iemitu and plotted to disinherit him.

sen.j: 二男・家光よりも三男・忠長を可愛がったのは、忠長が母・江の伯父・織田信長によく似ていたためであるともいう。
sen.e: It is also said that she loved her third son Tadanaga more than her second son Iemitu because Tadanaga looked alike his mother Go's uncle Nobunaga ODA.
It is also said that she loved her third son Tadanaga more than her second son Iemitu because Tadanaga looked like his mother Go's uncle Nobunaga ODA.

sen.j: 忠長の妻は織田信長の次男・織田信雄の孫娘であり、母・江がいかに織田家との血筋を重んじていたのかが伺える。
sen.e: Tadanaga's wife was a granddaughter of Nobukatsu ODA, the second son of Nobunaga ODA, and it is evident that how his mother Go valued the genealogy with the ODA family.
Tadanaga's wife was a granddaughter of Nobukatsu ODA, the second son of Nobunaga ODA, and it is evident that his mother Go valued the genealogy with the ODA family.

sen.j: 家光が実母より春日局になついていた事もあり、春日局の権力拡大を止めるため忠長を重んじていたとも考えられるので、一概には江を批判できない。
sen.e: Since Iemitsu was attached to Kasuga no tsubone rather than his real mother, it can be thought that Sugen-in treated Tadanaga preferentially to prevent Kasuga no tsubone from enlarging her power, thus, it is not necessarily appropriate to criticize Go.

sen.j: また、前述の作家永井は、江はむしろ性格的に似ている家光の方に親近感を抱いていたという解釈もしている。
sen.e: Further, the above-mentioned novelist NAGAI interpreted that Go rather had a sense of affinity to Iemitsu who had similar character to her.
